content.full_text:
FWO DMP
Project Name
 Vatican II and the African Struggle for Justice (GS 63-72): A Historical Study of the
Contribution of the African Bishops to â€œGaudium et Spesâ€​ and Its Reception in Africa
(Dioceses of Awka and Yaounde) 
- FWO DMP
Project Identifier
 1131022N
Grant Title
 1131022N
Principal Investigator / Researcher
 Chidiebere Obiora Nnabugwu
Project Data Contact
 +32 485 78 25 04, chidiebereobiora.nnabugwu@kuleuven.be
Description
 World poverty was one of the social questions that the Second Vatican Council
(1962-1965) took very close to heart. The Council Fathers, in the Pastoral Constitution
â€œGaudium et Spesâ€​ (GS), gave extensive thought to this injustice and proposed some
principles that should form the basis for promoting greater justice and equity in the socio-
economic life of people and among nations. Despite important awareness-raising and praxis-
oriented initiatives such as â€œJustitia et Paxâ€​ (1967) which was created â€œto stimulate the
Catholic Community to foster progress in needy regions and social justice on the international
sceneâ€​ (GS 90), poverty on the African continent has remained endemic. Using literary and
archival sources alongside oral history, this research aims (1) to interpret these conciliar
principles in order (2) to map out how the post-conciliar Roman Catholic Church in Africa has
worked to find solutions to the challenges of poverty and underdevelopment, which initiatives
have worked, and which have failed. The Church profiles herself in Africa as an institution that is
on the side of the poor. This research will examine how the Church in Africa understood the social
mandate she received at Vatican II and how she attempted to make it an integral part of her
social apostolate. This historical project will thus provide the basis for the generation of insights
that will help to enhance the Churchâ€™s commitment to social transformation and integral
development in Africa.
Institution
 KU Leuven
1. General Information
Name applicant
Chidiebere Obiora Nnabugwu
FWO Project Number & Title
FWO Project Number: 11331022N
FWO File Number: 90893
Title: Vatican II and the African Struggle for Justice (GS 63-72): A Historical Study of the
Contribution of the African Bishops to “Gaudium et Spes” and Its Reception in Africa (Dioceses of
Awka and Yaounde)
Affiliation
KU Leuven
History of Church and Theology Research Unit
Faculty of Theology and Religious Studies
2. Data description
Will you generate/collect new data and/or make use of existing data?
Generate new data

(estimated) volume. This may be easiest in a table (see example) or as a data flow and
per WP or objective of the project. If you reuse existing data, specify the source of
these data. 
Distinguish data types (the kind of content) from data formats (the
technical format).

3. Legal and ethical issues
Will you use personal data? 
If so, shortly describe the kind of personal data you will
use. Add the reference to your file in KU Leuven's Register of Data Processing for
Research and Public Service Purposes (PRET application). 
Be aware that registering
the fact that you process personal data is a legal obligation.
Yes
Privacy Registry Reference: E-2021-2673
Short description of the kind of personal data that will be used:
 The first work package involves the compilation of a limited prosopography of the African
bishops who participated in the preparation of the Second Vatican Council through the
submission of their vota. Their names, dates of birth and dates of death, places of origin, places
of apostolate, congregations or dioceses, and such ecclesial metadata will be collected in an
excel spreadsheet.
In the third year of the research, oral history interviews are envisaged for which approval will be
sought from SMEC. Audio recordings and transcriptions of the planned 10 one-hour-long
interviews will be generated.
Are there any ethical issues concerning the creation and/or use of the data (e.g.
experiments on humans or animals, dual use)? If so, add the reference to the formal
approval by the relevant ethical review committee(s)
Yes
The interviews, for which SMEC's approval will be sought in the third year, will focus on the
This document was generated by DMPonline (http://dmponline.dcc.ac.uk)
2 of 5
exercise of the social apostolate in Africa. I will obtain the permission of the interviewees to
record the interviews. These interviews will be recorded with a high-quality digital audio recorder
and transcribed to text with Microsoft Word to increase accessibility. The interviewees will get the
chance to review the transcripts. They will be duly informed about how and where these audio
files and their transcripts will be preserved, who will have access to them in the long term, and
that they at all times have the right to revoke the availability of the data.
 
Does your work possibly result in research data with potential for tech transfer and
valorisation? Will IP restrictions be claimed for the data you created? If so, for what
data and which restrictions will be asserted?
No
Do existing 3rd party agreements restrict dissemination or exploitation of the data
you (re)use? If so, to what data do they relate and what restrictions are in place?
No
4. Documentation and metadata
What documentation will be provided to enable reuse of the data collected/generated
in this project?
To be sure, the project’s framework is the constant research on the history and reception of
Vatican II. The digital and non-digital data that would be generated in this project would be non-
sensitive in nature.
That said, regarding WP1, the prosopography and the vota from Africa coded with NVivo
qualitative data analysis tool are envisaged to be published in a peer-reviewed data journal for
eternal preservation and availability for reuse.
The archival materials that will be collected in connection with WP2, WP3, and WP4 will be
properly identified and stored in the KU Leuven Centre for the Study of the Second Vatican
Council or the Centre's digital space for digital data to ensure permanent availability for reuse.
As for the interviews, the necessary information regarding the organization, conduct, informed
consent, and permissions for storage and dissemination will be put together with the
transcription of the interviews.
Will a metadata standard be used? If so, 
describe in detail which standard will be
used. 
If no, state in detail which metadata will be created to make the data
easy/easier to find and reuse.
No
See the previous question.
5. Data storage and backup during the FWO project
Where will the data be stored?
Data generated for this research project will be simultaneously saved in the KU Leuven J-Drive,
OneDrive, and an external hard drive.
How is backup of the data provided?
The KU Leuven OneDrive ensures automatic backup. I will also make frequent updates to my
external hard drive. 
Is there currently sufficient storage & backup capacity during the project? If yes,
specify concisely. If no or insufficient storage or backup capacities are available then
explain how this will be taken care of.
Yes
The KU Leuven OneDrive with 2 TB of storage space, the annual 50 GB space available at the
Research Data Repository,  the J-Drive, and an external hard disk with 1 TB storage capacity
suffice for storing and backing up data during the conduct of the research project. 
What are the expected costs for data storage and back up during the project? How
will these costs be covered?
This document was generated by DMPonline (http://dmponline.dcc.ac.uk)
3 of 5
The (basic) storage services detailed above are offered at no expense. Should the need arise to
secure some extra storage space, the costs will be footed through the PhD candidate's bench
fee.
Data security: how will you ensure that the data are securely stored and not accessed
or modified by unauthorized persons?
As aforementioned, data for this project will be non-sensitive in nature. In any case, password
protection will be employed to ensure controlled access to the data.
6. Data preservation after the FWO project
Which data will be retained for the expected 5 year period after the end of the
project? In case only a selection of the data can/will be preserved, clearly state the
reasons for this (legal or contractual restrictions, physical preservation issues, ...).
With the exception of the audio recordings, all data generated for this research will be stored
permanently in the said KU Leuven storage spaces, among other things, to forestall duplication
of efforts. 
Only the transcription of the audio files will be stored in these KU Leuven storage spaces. With
the permission of the interviewees, the raw audio recordings may be permanently stored in the
relevant diocesan repositories.
Where will the data be archived (= stored for the longer term)?
Textual data will be archived in the KU Leuven Centre for the Study of the Second Vatican
Council. Digital data will be reposed in the Centre's digital archive.
What are the expected costs for data preservation during the retention period of 5
years? How will the costs be covered?
No cost is foreseen for this preservation.
7. Data sharing and reuse
Are there any factors restricting or preventing the sharing of (some of) the data (e.g.
as defined in an agreement with a 3rd party, legal restrictions)?
No
Which data will be made available after the end of the project?
All data (except audio recordings) will be made available for reuse at the end of the project. As
for the interviews, the transcriptions will always be available.
Where/how will the data be made available for reuse?
Upon request by mail
Other (specify):
Some of the data will be published in peer-reviewed data journal(s). They will also be consultable
at the Centre for the Study of the Second Vatican Council.
When will the data be made available?
Immediately after the end of the project
Upon publication of the research results
Who will be able to access the data and under what conditions?
The data will be available at the Centre for the Study of the Second Vatican Council for historians
and theologians of Vatican II and for anyone interested in the subject of the social mission of the
Catholic Church in Africa. Thus, such researchers will have to abide by the guidelines stipulated
in the Centre's website
(https://theo.kuleuven.be/en/research/centres/centr_vatii/archive_consultation).
What are the expected costs for data sharing? How will the costs be covered?
None.
8. Responsibilities
Who will be responsible for data documentation & metadata?
This document was generated by DMPonline (http://dmponline.dcc.ac.uk)
4 of 5
The PhD student (Chidiebere Obiora Nnabugwu) and the Promoter (Prof. Dr. Dries Bosschaert)
who is currently the Coordinator of the Centre for the Study of the Second Vatican Council will
oversee data documentation and management.
Who will be responsible for data storage & back up during the project?
The PhD student (Chidiebere Obiora Nnabugwu) will be responsible.
Who will be responsible for ensuring data preservation and reuse ?
The PhD student (Chidiebere Obiora Nnabugwu) and the Promoter cum Coordinator of the Centre
of the Study of the Second Vatican Council (Prof. Dr. Dries Bosschaert) will be responsible.
Who bears the end responsibility for updating & implementing this DMP?
The Promoter (Prof. Dr. Dries Bosschaert) bears the end responsibility of updating &
implementing this DMP.
This document was generated by DMPonline (http://dmponline.dcc.ac.uk)
5 of 5
